div.head: From Yorktown
div.excerpt: "Yorktown was the grave of British oppression in our Revolutionary struggle for Liberty--God grant that, in 1862, Yorktown may prove to be the burial place of the last foe of Freedom and of the Republic on this continent."
div.summary: Reports that no decisive action has yet taken place at Yorktown. Predicts "one of the mot determined and sanguinary battles that has occurred in the present age."

div.head: Review of the Past Year
div.summary: "Occasional," the Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Press, looks back on the achievements of President Lincoln and his cabinet during the past year, briefly comparing Lincoln to Buchanan.

div.head: Recognition of Hayti and Liberia
div.summary: Reports that the Senate has passed a bill to allow the President to appoint diplomatic representatives to the countries of Haiti and Liberia.

div.head: Nineteen Repel [sic] Vessels Taken in the Rappahannock
div.summary: Reports that nineteen Southern ships have been captured.

div.head: Capture of New Orleans
div.summary: Preliminary reports that Union troops have taken New Orleans and that there has been "great destruction" of property, cotton, and steamboats in the city.

div.head: Fort Jackson in Possession of Our Troops
div.summary: Announces that Fort Jackson, six miles below Savannah, has been taken by Union forces.

div.head: From Gen. Halleck's Army
div.excerpt: "We captured twelve prisoners, none of whom expressed regret at being taken. They say the people [of the] South are sick of war."
div.summary: Reports that a reconnoitering party, under Brigadier-General A. J. Smith, routed about 3,000 to 4,000 of the enemy from Pea Ridge, Tennessee. In addition, news from Cairo reports that the Ohio River continues to rise.

div.head: Affairs at Yorktown
div.summary: Provides an account of the situation at Yorktown.

page.pageNote: Advertisements for political candidates, column 1; news from Cairo and from Mexico, column 4; news from Commodore Foote's Expedition, column 5

div.head: Town Meeting!
div.summary: Announces that a town meeting will be held for the Union Republican voters of Chambersburg in the court house next Friday evening. The purpose of the meeting will be to nominate candidates for town council, school directors, and borough constable.

div.head: Wounded
div.summary: Reports that a young man from Chambersburg, Jeremiah Bellis, was wounded in the leg at Pittsburg Landing and will arrive in this town shortly. He is a member of Captain Wishart's company.

div.head: Died from Wounds
div.summary: Relates that the name of the soldier from Captain Wishart's company that died from wounds he received at Pittsburg Landing was Thomas J. M'Elwee, of Franklin County.

div.head: Noble Act
div.summary: Reports on the Union meeting held at the Lutheran Church the previous Sunday evening. The various congregations of Chambersburg met together to listen to the Reverend Mr. Cross of Baltimore speak. Donations given at the meeting are to go to books and tracts that will be distributed among soldiers in camp and hospitals.

div.head: Improvements
div.summary: Lists the many improvements being effected in Chambersburg of late.

div.head: Rejoicing
div.excerpt: "The conquest of the hell-hatched, Slave-drivers Rebellion goes bravely on. Long live the Republic!"
div.summary: Notes that the national flag was raised in the public square and bells were rung when the news was received that Union forces had taken New Orleans and Fort Jackson.

div.head: In Hospital
div.summary: Reports that James A. Ritner, son of Mrs. Ritner of Chambersburg and grandson of former Governor Ritner, is in the soldier's hospital in Cincinnati, due to a wound he suffered at Pittsburg Landing. He is a member of the Third Iowa regiment.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Jacob Held and Miss Mary Bowers, both of Chambersburg, were married in the German Lutheran Church on the previous Sunday evening.

div.head: Deaths
div.summary: Dr. A. B. Madden, aged 32 years, died at his residence in Loudon on March 29.

div.head: What Shall Be Done with the Enfranchised Negroes?
div.summary: Asks why the United States has not yet put to work the former slaves on the government's fortifications.

div.head: Honor to Whom Honor is Due
div.excerpt: "To be the author of such acts is an honor of which any might well be proud."
div.summary: Points out that the bill to free the slaves in the District of Columbia was authored by Colonel Keyes of McClellan's staff, a lawyer from Ohio. While still in Ohio, he also drew up the bill giving married women a right to the result of their own labor and the right to hold property in their own name.

div.head: The Suppression of the African Slave Trade
div.summary: Reports that the Senate has unanimously approved the Seward-Lyons treaty that attempts to destroy the "last vestige" of the African slave trade.

div.excerpt: "Vallandigham is a disgrace to the House and should be turned over to the traitors and rebels of the South whose tool he is, and to whom he legitimately belongs."
div.summary: Denounces Vallandigham for calling Senator Wade "a liar, a scoundrel, and a coward" and expresses the wish that the resolution of censure of Vallandigham that has been introduced would be transformed into a resolution of expulsion and then passed.
Speculates that in many portions of the South, Southerners are not aware of the Union victories that have occurred because of "misrepresentation" of these victories by "the rebel leaders."
